narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Michael William Stone  Strengths: Really added value to discussions and helped provide some structure to the class when the professor was unavailable/somewhat scatter-brained. There were a few unscheduled hiccups for this class and he handled them well. Weaknesses: A little bit more structure would be even more helpful. For instance, organizing case reading materials a little bit earlier or scheduling make-up classes with more notice.
Instructor: Michael William Stone  -Opinionated, knowledgeable, up-to-date knowledge, & open to student perspectives

Instructor: Michael William Stone  The class overall was slightly disorganized and while Michael was helpful when I spoke to him in person the overall confusion regarding course requirements was a little frustrating.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course structure/style takes a little bit of getting used to, especially if you're not from a social science background. The professor can ramble a bit at times and can be hard to follow during lectures. However, most of the class is student-led discussion, not lectures, and here the professor does a good job of poking at interesting questions. It is a valuable addition to more application-based CSR classes from the business school, as this course gets you thinking about the "why" rather than the "how" of CSR.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The term paper, which gave me an opportunity to take a deep dive into an issue of CSR, and really learn about it

Analyzing concrete examples of CSR, the intimate feeling of the small group discussions and class, and the flexibility of the final paper. Insightful TA, kind professor, interesting guest speakers (2).
The professor and teaching assistant are very knowledgeable and passionate about the topic, which really showed.
-Gaining insight to various examples of CSR in different industries, this was great & it was nice to choose the topics!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I believe the 3 hour classes are too long, breaking the course into two classes a week would probably be better for students.

The readings could use some fine-tuning, given that they're such a critical element of this class. Less time should be spent on the readings from the earlier half of the semester, which is dominated by governance models and frameworks. 3 hours is a too much time to have to analyze 4 governance readings within a small class. It would be beneficial if the earlier model/governance articles were paired with concrete examples of CSR so that our discussions could be more grounded. The second half of the semester was more interesting, in my opinion, as we got to pick our case topics. However, we should again strive to keep them grounded in specific examples of CSR innovations (sometimes the readings for the "cases" were just governance/model articles).

I think this course should not be three hours long! we ran out of things to talk about and started talking in circles. The length seems unnecessary for the material we cover, two hours would be plenty of time. Or more topics should be covered per class (but with fewer readings per topic) or the professor should lecture for at least part of the class. I also think the case studies should have been of individual/company initiatives in different industries (perhaps comparing different initiatives to tackle the same problems).

-Needs more structure / formal lectures so we can take the information to another level --it was a lot of shallow analysis that resulted in asking the same questions repeated. -DIRECTLY address in a pre-planned lecture, how to apply all this CSR knowledge in practice --the theories mean something, but how can we take this knowledge with us and apply it!?! --> this is important

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: At first I struggled to feel comfortable with the somewhat vague discussions in this class, but I think I grew into it and began to see value in discussing questions that don't have answers. It's a valuable addition to more application-based courses, as it gets you asking the right questions.
- I plan to be a CSR manager or environmental consultant

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in corporate social responsibility/corporate sustainability and want to work in this field.
interest in CSR
See question 20.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes

Mostly, yes. My expectations were a little off, as I thought this class would be more practical. But once I realized it was more theoretical it helped me get a difference set of skills. Adding a little structure and case-based examples to the readings would improve our knowledge uptake.
I think some more hard/practical/implementation skills would be good to be incorporated into the course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

I liked being able to focus on just 2-3 readings at a time for one topic, which allowed me to focus my analysis. However, this wasn't really group work... we didn't have any group deliverables and didn't have to coordinate until the day of the presentation.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's important to really understand what the purpose of this class is, and to have realistic expectations. It's not meant to be a "how-to" of CSR, like some other courses taught by FES/SOM. Instead, it's more of a "why" exploration of CSR. That's valuable in its own way, so consider whether you are interested in exploring questions about CSR without necessarily getting answers.
-Expect classes and information to be scattered/disorganized. You will need to sift through the information and pull lessons yourself. Good content and important topics to think about; worth taking.
